oDE XXIX TO ICCIUS.

O, Icciu5‚ thou hast hankerings For swart Arabia’s golden treasure5‚ And for her still unconquered kings Art marshalling war's deadly measures, And forging setters meant to tame The Mede, our curse and shame?

Say, what barbarian virgin fair Shall wait on thee, that slew her lover, What princely boy‚ with perfumed hair, Thy cupbearer, shall round thee hover, Schooled by his sire, with fatal craft To wing the Seric shast?

Up mountains steep may glide the brooks, And Tiber to its sources roam,

When thou canst change thy noble books Culled far and near, and learned home,

For armour dipped in Ebro’s wave,

Who once such promise gave!
